Title: The Johan Falk Trilogy

reviewText: The Johan Falk Trilogy is very strong on action and suspense. There are car chases aplenty, shootouts and fairly complex plot lines. In some ways, the three episodes appear to be modeled after US crime thrillers, quite unlike the Nordic Noir series I like best: Beck, Wallander, The Bridge, The Killing, The Protectors. Character development is skimpy, and there are not many layers of "action behind the action", not to mention the social critique characteristic for recent Scandinavian productions. Jacob Eklund does not portray an engaging character. This may be due to the script, but also to his exceedingly bland acting: he has two or three standard facial expressions, that's it. The other characters also come across as fairly two-dimensional. All in all, this is suspenseful entertainment, but not memorable at all.
Title: The Johan Falk Trilogy

reviewText: I wasn't sure what I was getting into with the opening scene of Episode 1 -- it was a strange way to introduce so vital and forceful a character.  The viewer is kept off-balance wondering "Who IS this guy?" as our protagonist watches cartoons, saves boxes of toys and picks up a woman in a cafe for a surprisingly matter-of-fact tryst on Christmas Eve.  But then, the real story begins with a wallop of excitement.  The pace never really returns to that strange, languid opening segment.  I won't repeat a synopsis of the three episodes since a previous reviewer did a splendid job of that already.  However, I will say that my husband and I were enthralled by the freshness of the plots, their intricacy, and the fact that they prompt some serious thought long after the episode ends.  The subject matter is timely and relevant to the multiplicity of issues swirling around the burgeoning global economy (and some of the unintended consequences that result).  My only real criticism concerns the character development of Johan Falk -- could use a bit more work.  He's painted in bold brush strokes with very little subtlety.  He is clearly both valued and disliked by his colleagues and friends.  He's prickly and self-absorbed.  It's hard to get the real measure of Falk or the background for the strong personal connections and tensions he inspires.  Still, the intelligence of the plots, the intensity of the human drama that unfolds around him, and the high-octane action sequences in each episode make for an absorbing and exciting viewing experience.  Highly recommended.
Title: The Johan Falk Trilogy

reviewText: The "Johan Falk Trilogy" is a compilation of three feature films (each on its own disc) that detail the adventures of a Swedish cop dealing with murder, corruption, and political intrigue across the continent of Europe.  If you like hard-boiled Scandinavian noir, this trilogy of films should offer enough excitement and violence to keep you entertained.  With the international success of Stieg Larsson's Millennium Trilogy (The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo) and its subsequent film adaptations, there seems to have been a renewed interest in discovering works from this geographic region.  Horrible brutality is often juxtaposed with apparent affluence and serenity and it's a startling contrast.  In fact, some of my favorite DVD compilations of the past year have been imported Scandinavian TV crime drama.  When it comes to crime drama, though, there is very little that we haven't seen.  So oftentimes, whether or not you connect with a story has to do with how it is interpreted and who you have to guide you.  Johan Falk, in my opinion, is a terrific character brought to life by Jakob Eklund with just the right mix of brashness and bravado.It might be important to note, however, that these movies are not exactly contemporary.  These films were actually released between 1999 and 2003.  They serve as the introduction to Falk, and the series continued on in 2009 and 2012 with another twelve adventures.Included in this set:Zero Tolerance (1999) 3 1/2 Stars: Despite having its detractors, this movie was a huge success in Sweden marking one of their first forays into big budget action.  It begins with an impressive chase and shoot-out, but settles into a rather conventional storyline (albeit one that is well executed).  Happening upon a jewel heist, Falk chases down one culprit in a series of events that leaves an innocent bystander killed.  Despite having plenty of witnesses to the affair, the notorious criminal exerts his influence and this leaves Falk twisting in the wind for the death.  To prove his innocence, he must take matters into his own hands to apprehend the real criminals.  Well acted by the principles (Jacob Eklund, Marie Richardson and Peter Andersson), the experience might have benefited by a little more shading in characterizations.  We're never supposed to doubt Falk, even as the movie favors a good cop's autonomy over the entire judicial system.Executive Protection (2001) 3 1/2 Stars: This follow-up takes our hero even further into isolation, he really doesn't seem to play well with others.  Still a black sheep in the department, Falk answers a call for help from his friend Sven Perrson (Samuel Fröler).  A successful and wealthy businessman, Persson runs afoul of the Russian mafia and has no easy way to extricate himself from a life of blackmail and threats.  He thinks that hiring an ex-Stasi agent (Christoph M. Ohrt) is the answer, but that just opens up a new can of worms.  Trust me, though, in these circumstances--Falk is a good friend to have!  Although this plays to fairly conventional action movie standards (it's a bit over-the-top truthfully), there are some nice set pieces.  I especially enjoyed the race through the Swedish forest.The Third Wave (2003) 4 Stars:  When this installment was released, it had the highest budget ever of any Swedish film.  In my opinion, though, it is the best of the trilogy.  While the first two movies were set in Sweden, "The Third Wave" becomes a thriller that shoots all over Europe.  When a young woman inadvertently discovers that her boyfriend launders money for a European mob, it sets off a chain of events that may cost her life.  An ex-colleague tries to lure Falk into a position with Europol, but their initial meeting is interrupted by a ruthless assassin who has his sights on the young couple.  As always, Falk ends up in the middle of things and the ensuing chase leads across Europe.  Although well structured, the movie gets a bit zanier as it progresses with moments that are both over-the-top and too reliant on convenience.  But I liked the scope and ambition of this one and found it fitfully amusing.  KGHarris, 10/13.
summary: A Trio Of Swedish Action Blockbusters Finally Get A North American DVD Release
